Hi guys, I have two HubSpot CTA's – one of which needs to scroll to a destination on the page, and the other needs to open a light-box video player. Is this even possible? They aren't linking to an internal or external page, likely going to need to include some JS... Thoughts?
not certain but can you use #links

for scrolling you need to add as href="#ID-of-Section" and on the section that you want to scroll to you have to add the ID that you have put in the link. (you will need some JS to make a smooth scroll else will teleport to the section, google a smooth scoll js code). As for the popup video, yes for that you need JS something like on click (event) that button open the popup. now depends on how have you build the popup up
if you cant set a `/#id` link in the cta then  you could use a query parameter and trigger javascript off of it.  to fire off the modal, or kick you down
Where would the js be included? Would I wrap the Hubl in an <a> tag?
I would suggest to just make it a rich text button, cause a CTA that does nothing doesn't captures data, correct me if I am wrong.
Well if you do link to a url with a # or a query parameter it theoretically will still log the data
for sure if you do a query param
because then it actually loads a new url
true, unless is on the same page
The best option will be to use a custom button not go with cta I think parameter url will not allow to create a cta
Well ideally we'd like to collect data, how many people are clicking it, etc.
and this will take full url of the page so when ever you click this will redirect to the page url

my best suggestion is if you are not so confident about the code and the button doesn't actually captures data, just make 2 simple buttons instead else is going to be tricky to work around a CTA with js
I would say chandler give it a shot using the CTA, link to either # or a query parameter and see what it does. If it works. then that’s your best bet to log the data
now I don't remember perfectly but I remember being an issue with CTA's when trying to interact them with a custom JS file because loads after and your script will not take place.

Do you happen to have an example of this markup, example, if i'm using `{% cta "project_cta" label='start a project', guid='ccd39b7c-ae18-4c4e-98ee-547069bfbc5b', image_src='<https://no-cache.HubSpot.com/cta/default/53/c7335b66-a0d4-4d19-82eb-75e1626d02d0.png>' %}` how do you implement JS into that?
right what I’m saying is DO NOT ADD AN ON CLICK handler use the URL instead. Then there’s no conflict.
for non HS CTA's I use `<a class="scroll-button scrollto" href="#intro">`
But url will not simple this will be something differ then how you can track it
you use javascript to detect if there’s a # in the url and trigger smooth scroll if that’s what you’re wanting
the hubl code needs to be first converted into HTML, see what it outputs in the inspect element and try targeting the genated code via JS
but if you add an onClick handler to the CTA, then you don’t get the stats
yes but you will need that for the popup video, unless you do it with :target pure css popup. but if a Plugin, you might need to...
oy… you guys you’re actually overcomplicating it. you don’t need to do any of that at all, you can leave the generated code as it is
onclick event will work for same page if page is not reloading while cta will oad page itself then how this will work?

Is anyone doing anything besides the use of captcha (which is almost useless, anymore), to minimize spam comments on blogs?
Disabling comments!
Lol, was really tempted to say that. It is seriously what we do... lol
Same, I don’t think I’ve ever seen a legitimate comment on a blog we’ve developed where we have left it on. Could just be the businesses we work with.
And seeing a whole blog with 700 posts only three comments is depressing.

you could leave it open but only allow NLP / machine-learning bots to respond to each other based on the content… i.e. one summarizes, then the other responds with criticism of it and so on down the chain until it’s just 0's and 1's
lmao, basically a "good bot - bad bot" bot. I like it.
It would be REALLY interesting to actually put into place
who’s got a client they’re comfortable sneaking this into?

*Out of curiosity, When QAing a HS website what does everyone typically tend to do?*
I’ll use our process as an example:
• we run through the site/pages with sauce labs in all of the relevant browsers fix any browser compatibility issues we find
• send our work to one of the other developers on our team to QA against the mockup fix any issues they find
• If all looks good we notify client.

Just wondering to see if we can improve our process. I know some teams use checklists and things, just wondering what everyone does
Where does internal testing of the HubSpot components / modules come in? Or are you specifically referencing FE stuff?

We create to-do lists in Basecamp for each template with a link to an example, then have a senior member run through each template while looking at the concepts/branding docs. I usually look at each section while dragging around the window to check responsive. Then we use browserstack to check other platforms, then have someone go through the lists, then the last item is for a senior person to look it over again in case on QA item’s fix broke something (always happens).
Then handoff to client and we make a list that they can populate with anything they find.
And we have whoever is working on the fixes assign the tasks back to the person who did the testing so that they can confirm that it has been done.
what are you meaning by `FE`?
Front-end
Also the Basecamp to-do items are nice because you can drag screenshots in there to explain what’s wrong.

ahh, to answer your question, if a module is going to be used in different ways on a site we have the other dev try out the different settings to make sure we didn’t just make it work for one specific scenario.
<@U26DA9CQ0> thanks for sharing, that’s pretty close to how our team does it. The key difference i see in your system is it looks like 2 people QA each person’s work?.
If anyone need HubSpot developer or qa. I have some in my connection.

<@U7SL518D6> Unless someone gets pulled off onto another project it is usually one person generating the lists of items and one or more developers going through the lists fixing things. We try to have someone other than the primary dev creating the lists.
in the work directory should be a modules folder

Hello. I am new to HubSpot COS and the new site I am building does have a lot of pages that have a large CTA at the top, but those pages are critical to the architecture of the web site, and thus cannot remove navigation and generally should treat them as web site pages. 

However, I am unclear on the real difference between a landing page and a website page - especially since web site pages now have a/b split testing. Does anyone have an article I can reference?

Landing Pages show different statistics. The main difference is their purpose.

Landing pages are for pages with forms, which try to lead people down the funnel.

Website pages, are your general site pages.

Example: say you have a new promotion on social media for a sweepstakes - the page you’d link to you’d want to be a landing page, to collect the user’s data, then throw them to a thank you page and “delight” them
CTAs generally link to Landing Pages. (You can obviously use them however you want, but generally speaking that’s the theory behind them)
Got it, that makes a lot of sense. Thanks Jon!

I know that HubSpot COS v2 was just launched a few weeks ago, and thus some modules needed to be upgraded.
I will be making NEW modules as a part of this web site, but since I’m new to this eco system, I don’t know what is accepted in v2 and what’s from v1 when looking at the documentation.

Is the documentation up to date? or are there release notes about this update?

<https://designers.HubSpot.com/transitioning-from-v1-to-v2-modules>

The documentation is up-to-date. and as far as transitioning old modules you’ll find the design manager error screen tells you if something isn’t going to work
and wont let you publish the new upgraded version until you’ve solved the problems preventing downtime

If you had any modules that used certain hubl functions they will need updating: <https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/modules/reference#restricted-hubl>

All of the functions though that are gone have a workaround in the new design manager
perfect, thanks.

Yeah got them, am I missing something though? Those custom modules are single json files not like those i’ve created within HubSpot? When I grab them via FTP they are folders / v2.

Working locally do I need to convert these modules in some way so they work within templates? Only you can’t create them like vast has and upload them via FTP because of permissions and what I would of taken as a normal usage snippet doesn’t display anything.

Just wondering really if Local HubL server even supports custom modules fully?
